title: Seg Violation
body:

Geth version: canotical current
OS & Version: Ubuntu


#### Expected behaviour

#### Actual behaviour
seg violation


#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
geth --mine --minerthreads 4 --etherbase '0x.......'

@linas Thanks for the report! We did find and fixed an issue a while back that caused some of these problems (at least on Windows). Since then most users stopped opening issues so we thought this was fixed. If it is still breaking for you, there is probably a second issue too, will need to take a closer look at your stack dumps.

I've done a little digging into `sealer.go` and it looks like the specific call that is consistently panicking is the call to `ethash.mine(block, id, nonce, abort, found)`.

I'm trying to work backwards and recompiled from commit `b801be99d47ba09121a3e7d14aa028f828525b61` to see if it was the April-ish consensus changes that are related to this bug. Perhaps one of the header fields or something in the Block struct is nil when passed in. :thinking:

It won't fail immediately.  For me, it failed maybe 3 times in one week, and then ran fine for 2+ weeks, before I reported above. Currently, its been running fine 5 days straight.

There's two explanations for intermittent crashes: (1) race conditions (2) hostile attacks.

Does ethereum have a hostile-data test?  Some carefully crafted packet that causes the miner to crash? 

I monitor my IP traffic, and noticed that hostile stuff comes in spurts (martian fragments, icmp redirects, ssh passwd guesses) - it makes sense that someone would try to send hostile ethereum packets, and try to get a shell on the victims machine. I mean, lots of someones could be very financially motivated to do this.

That's quite odd. My instinct is that it is a race condition, since I have seen no such issues using the Parity client on the same mining machine for 24+ hours. But I'll see.

I am thinking a next debugging step will be to step through each package in master and compile using the race detector. There is no good reason I can see for a runtime panic other than a data race.
